Your assumptions are wrong on so many counts. Humanities departments are usually the smallest and cheapest departments at state universities. English professors make less than biochemistry professors, and they do not need special labs to do their research. Building even one scientific research center costs hundreds of millions of dollars. This is fine as far as I'm concerned--universities need both disciplines, and society values science over the liberal arts. But it is just a right-wing fantasy that millions of dollars is spent funding women's studies or African-American studies. Where they exist, these are often only interdisciplinary programs, which means their cross-listed courses are taught by professors housed in English, poli sci, and history departments. Do consult a college catalog, and learn how to read it.

" English professors make less than biochemistry professors, and they do not need special labs to do their research. Building even one scientific research center costs hundreds of millions of dollars."

Yes, but unlike like most English professors, biochemistry professors fund their own research with competitively acquired private and public grants, of which approximately 50% will be taken off the top to fund the university. Building a research center is an investment by the university in the future millions of dollars of research grants their faculty will have to acquire should they have any hope of achieving tenure. Same goes for all the life sciences, chemistry, physics, engineering, etc.

The biochemistry professors make more because their skill sets are much more valuable than those of English professors in the private labor market. They also supplement their own salary with private and public research grants

The science departments contribute to the operating costs of the university, unlike almost any humanities department. The economic liabilities of humanities vs. science departments are nothing alike.
I'm sure you have some actual numbers to go with this gut feeling of yours.

Over the last two or three decades, colleges, both public and private have made an enormous investment in programs that could at best be called pseudo-disciplines.  it is not necessary to enumerate them here. It suffices to  say that they center about "gender", race, sexual identity.and the myriad forms of oppression.  Needless to say, they have attracted a full complement of pseudo-scholars, who in time have become tenured and endowed with the full array of benefits, health and retirement, of other faculty.  In addition the already bloated administration of these institutions has been augmented by an army of utterly useless factotums gathered together under the heading of "diversity".  I am not able to say how much this phenomenon has added to the costs of higher education, but it must be considerable.  I invite anyone who thinks I am making this up to consult the course catalogues and staffing of public institutions in their area..

Right.

It's also the case that the labor that a university employs has been getting more expensive relative to the increase in the *average* salary. Even though average income has only risen modestly over the last three decades, income for very highly skilled workers in every profession: medicine, law, business, engineering, you name it, has gone up substantially. Such highly skilled workers are not all in the 1% but they are all in "the 5%." As universities must compete at least somewhat on wages with the private sector in order to attract and keep strong faculty, faculty salaries have risen much faster than inflation. Most faculty could still make substantially more if they moved to the private sector. But private sector dynamics have dramatically increased university labor costs.

There is also the question of the salaries of top administrators. At one state university with which I'm familiar, all the money available for real salary increases for faculty and administrators in the last 10 years has gone to the top administrators.

Everyone wants their take out food delivered fast and hot.  As a society, we give license to restaurants to keep their promise at all costs--these unlicensed, unguided motorized missiles who use the corner sidewalk curb cuts to ride down 4-foot wide sidewalks (narrowed by tree pits and other street furniture) to keep us fed.  Unfortunately, by tolerating motorized missiles (16-20 mph is five times the speed of a pedestrian), we leave the elderly, toddlers and dogs especially at risk, a life threatening fact glossed over in this romantic treatise.  The dangers of riding without lights or helmet, driving the wrong way or the death-defying 6-lane dive-bombs put everyone at risk.  Restaurants need to be held accountable.  Bicyclists and motorized cyclists need to be licensed.  This article makes a sham of the public's right to safe streets and sidewalks.  The next time a speeding food deliverer hits a person, dog or kid, I would like to put their next of kin in touch with this writer.  There is no alternative to safety--even if it means that we wait a little longer for food, create and enforce workable safety laws and tip better!

While there certainly is waste in higher education, it is not nearly as great as it seems, and it is not found in requiring students to take classes outside their majors. The importance of 'soft skills' for engineering types is well known. Engineers, e.g., will need to be able to write well and should have a broad knowledge base also outside of their major so that they have a better idea of the effects of what they do on society. Likewise, non-engineers need training in mathematics and sciences to have an idea what the sciences are about. It's called 'wisdom', and even though you cannot teach it, giving students a broader base for their thinking is an important first step.

A list of the usual commonly accepted prejudices without an backing facts or data.

Tuition has risen so dramatically at both public and private schools since the 1970s. The problem is more complex than merely a lack of state funding. Upward pressures on tuition include:

1. State budget cuts. These cuts are more or less inversely proportional to state Medicaid obligations. Future costs for pensions and increased Medicaid requirements under Obamacare will only worsen the problem.

2. Technology and student services. Computer labs and other technology on campus mean that universities now fund expensive technology divisions that never existed before. Counseling services, academic support services, diversity centers, university housing programming, etc., are all relatively new to campuses. This all costs money.

3. Federal tuition assistance. Tuition began to outpace inflation about 40 years ago after the introduction of the Pell Grants and subsidized Stafford loans. Tuition has risen faster than inflation by about the same amount as federal subsidies provide. Subsidies increase demand for spaces in colleges, and colleges pocket the money to pay for new services and programs.

4. Student loans. It used to be that almost nobody expected to take loans. Now, almost everybody does. If colleges can charge more and still fill seats, they generally will.

5. University grants. Colleges discount their sticker prices by giving grants to most students. Setting tuition higher and discounting more actually can add prestige and attract more students.

That's just sick. In this era of free agency, last seasons' teammate is next season's opponent - and vice versa. That should make for great team chemistry.

You want to stop the bounty system?  Provide a very serious punishment.  Like cancel the teams 2012 season.  Harsh yes, and it really punishes the fans.  But nothing says loving like cold hard cash, and hitting the wallets from top to down will insure no other team ever thinks of doing it again.

Professional sports, especially football have long since ceased being "sports."  Period.  They make obscene amounts of money for a trivial activity.  The most astonishing thing here is the piddling amounts they accept as bonuses for injuring another player.  They have no shame.
